title: List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Tyne and Wear
text:
There are 37 <a href="Sites%20of%20Special%20Scientific%20Interest">Sites of Special Scientific Interest</a> (SSSIs) in <a href="Tyne%20and%20Wear">Tyne and Wear</a>, <a href="England">England</a>. In England, the body responsible for designating SSSIs is <a href="Natural%20England">Natural England</a>, which chooses sites because of their <a href="plant">flora</a>, <a href="fauna">fauna</a>, <a href="geology">geological</a> or physiographical features. Natural England took over the role of designating and managing SSSIs from <a href="English%20Nature">English Nature</a> in October 2006 when it was formed from the amalgamation of English Nature, parts of the <a href="Countryside%20Agency">Countryside Agency</a> and the <a href="Rural%20Development%20Service">Rural Development Service</a>. Natural England, like its predecessor, uses the <a href="Metropolitan%20and%20non-metropolitan%20counties%20of%20England">1974–1996 county system</a> with each area being called an <a href="Area%20of%20Search">Area of Search</a>.
<a href="Tyne%20and%20Wear">Tyne and Wear</a> is made up of five administrative local authorities consisting mainly of the two largest cities in the region: <a href="Newcastle-upon-Tyne">Newcastle-upon-Tyne</a> and <a href="Sunderland%2C%20Tyne%20and%20Wear">Sunderland</a>, thus making it the <a href="List%20of%20conurbations%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom">sixth largest conurbation</a> in the <a href="United%20Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>. Tyne and Wear shares its borders with <a href="Northumberland">Northumberland</a> and <a href="County%20Durham">County Durham</a>, to the north and south respectively.
